title: Do you agree with Martin Heidegger in his idea that technology should only be seen as one of the approaches in perceiving truth? What are the other possible approaches that we should consider? - Quora

response.answer_text: The German philosopher Martin Heidegger (1889–1976) saw 20th century Europe as a historical period dominated by the being of all entities construed as available for use and manipulation (by human beings). Thus, the natural world (forests, rivers, animals) is understood as a giant stockroom of material waiting to be used up in human projects. It’s easy to misunderstand Heidegger’s point if you see all this as something that modern people (we) project onto already existing and perceived stuff (out there)—he claims that this is how the being of all entities is unconcealed and disclosed in the first place (in our era). It is not one human perspective among many that we might adopt (and then discard for a different perspective). Heidegger was not a humanist. He did not believe that all meaning and significance and understanding derive from human cognition or consciousness (as Sartre did). Heidegger was aware that over the last 3,000 years there have been different manifestations of the being of all entities (during the Middle Ages all entities were experienced as creations of God). But Heidegger doesn’t think that we today can recapture this particular dispensation of being anymore than the experience of the unconcealment of all entities by Parmenides and Heraclitus in pre-Socratic times can really be shared by we modern people. Note: None of this has anything to do with, as you put it in your question, “approaching truth”. When discussing Heidegger it’s best to avoid the term “truth” altogether (he uses this term in an eccentric manner).
